The factory that I have mentioned has offered to purchase 20,000 bags of maize a month from one part of my electorate, and will manufacture that maize into glucose and other things, such as starch, cornflour, oil, and calf food. An immense quantity of maize is grown in America, India, and South Africa, and more cheaply than we can grow it. We must protect our manufacturers from the dumping by America of glucose made from surplus maize. The Webb Act of 1918 makes legal the existence in the United States of America of Combines and Trusts formed to dumb surplus products into foreign markets, though ordinary Trusts and Combines are illegal in that country. Transport facilities are also given to enable products destined for export, either raw or in a manufactured state, to get to the seaboard cheaply. Dumping has, for a time, seriously affected the carbide making industry of Tasmania. It will be months before the stock of carbide that was dumped here is sufficiently diminished to allow of the Tasmanian product being sold again. "We should not allow the dumping of glucose, following on a good maize season in America, to injure our glucose industry and maize farmers.

.- I approve of the suggestion to increase the duty on glucose by 2s. The article is largely used in the making of confectionery, among other things. Competition in the United States of America is supported with huge capital, and directed by organized minds of the highest capacity. It creates a trade war as pitiless as any ordinary war. A duty of 10s. per cwt. is only a little over1d. per lb. Australian confectionery will hold its own against the world. I have blindfolded individuals, and got them to taste the highest grade of European chocolates and the chocolates made by MacRobertson, and have found that they could not tell the difference between the two. The OH Gold chocolate made by this Victorian firm is a line of which I can speak highly. I do not know of anything superior to it. If the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) will move an amendment in the direction he has suggested, I shall have much pleasure in supporting him.

. - I intend to support the proposal of the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser), particularly in the direction of assisting in the production of maize. In times of scarcity the value of maize in the past has been as high as 5s. and 5s. 6d. per bushel, but on occasions the price has been as low as 2e. 9d. per bushel, at which figure it was absolutely unprofitable to grow it. However, the operations of the Maize Products Company have in recent years brought about marvellous developments in maize production.
- The company are prepared to guarantee to take all the maize they can get at 4s. 6d. per bushel.

- Stabilizing maize at a price of 4s. 6d. per bushel would make its production a valuable industry for Australia. I understand that the Maize Products Company feel fairly secure in regard to all the products of maize they are turning out in their establishment, except in respect to glucose.
- What is the value of glucose ?
- At 5s. per bushel for maize the bare cost of manufacturing it is about £32 per ton in Australia.

- I understand the company have just got down to the bed-rock cost at which they can operate without loss. But while their operations are considerable for a new industry, and for a new country, they are a mere flea-bite when compared with the extent to which glucose is manufactured in America. We have an overwhelming market for the various products of maize - there are six turned out by this company - and if further assistance in the manufacture of glucose will assist an important local industry, we ought to give it.

.- When I adjusted this schedule I left the Division, Sugar, severely alone, and, of course, glucose is included in that division. I am aware that it is a product largely manufactured from maize, but, nevertheless, glucose is the raw material for other industries. For instance, makers of confectionery use a great deal of it. However, I feel inclined to accept the suggestion of the honorable member for Wide Bay to increase the duty on glucose, particularly in view of the fact that the Americans are beginning to dump it into Australia at a price which will have a very prejudicial effect on a local industry, which, by absorbing large quantities of a primary product, is most valuable to the primary producers of Australia, particularly the small farmers situated in coastal areas.
- Will the Minister fix the price of the maize at the factory, so that the small farmer will get some advantage ?
- This company has already offered to take 20,000 bags of maize per month from a portion of my electorate.

- It is impossible for us to do what the honorable member for Swan has suggested ; but as there is more than one manufacturer, and as others besides these factories are users of maize, the people to whom the honorable member refers will have no opportunity of rigging the market. Competition will compel them to pay the market price. At the same time the factories are very useful to the primary producers when there is a big surplus of maize, because they take vast quantities which otherwise could not be absorbed. The honorable member for Robertson (Mr. Fleming) knows very well the extent to which small farmers in New South Wales grow maize. Small farmers in Queensland and Victoria also grow it extensively, and although it may not- be cultivated much in Western Australia, nevertheless it is a very valuable product of the soil. I move -

quote.para: That the item he amended by adding the following: - " And on and after 14th May, 1021, per. cwt., British, 12s.; intermediate, 12s.; general, 12s."

talk.start.para: .- I quite realize the value of building up an industry, and I can quite appreciate the Minister's argument which will, no doubt, be brought forward again when we are dealing with the duty on agricultural* machinery, but, nevertheless, see- . ing that the duty on glucose is now 8s. per cwt., it seems a most extraordinary procedure to increase it by 50 per cent.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.
Item, as amended, agreed to.
Item 28-

quote.para: Sugar, the produce of sugar-cane, peT cwt.,
As.

talk.start.para: .- I would like to know whether at the present time the Minister is allowing any rebate upon sugar used in the preparation of confectionery exported from Australia.
- And in the manufacture of jams

- The point I wish to make is that tens of thousands of acres of land have been laid out for fruit culture upon which thousands of soldiers have settled. It is possible that within a few years the production of fruit in Australia will be so enormous that it will be necessary for us to do all we possibly can to build up a big export trade in jams and preserved fruits. Nothing could be superior to the preserved fruit I saw at Shepparton the other day. I want to know if the Minister has considered the question of allowing a rebate of duty on the sugar employed in- the manufacture of jam or the preservation of fruit for export, and whether at the present time a rebate is not given to the manufacture of confectionery exported from Australia or to firms like Swallow and Ariell, who use large quantities of sugar in the manufacture of the commodities they export.

. - I had better set out the whole position, so that there may be no misunderstanding hereafter. Under normal conditions when there are no such things as sugar agreements, and so forth, sugar is imported and then used in the manufacture of jams or for canning fruits for export. A rebate of duty is allowed on this imparted sugar to the full extent of the quantity so used. There is a system by which the Customs authorities arrive at the amount of sugar contained in jams and preserved fruits. Where sugar is exported in the form of jam or canned fruits, a rebate is allowed upon the full amount of it so used. We have never had a series of years when the Australian production of sugar has been equal to the local consumption. There has always been a certain amount of importation.
- It does not necessarily follow that the manufacturers who secure a rebate have used nothing but imported sugar.
- No.
- But you do not allow a rebate to the extent of more than the importation.

- The quantity upon which a rebate has been allowed has never yet come up to the amount , of sugar imported. During the. war definite agreements were in force under which the Commonwealth purchased sugar and supplied it to the jam manufacturers and fruit, preservers. Speaking from memory, I think we sold sugar to them for export purposes over a period of thr.ee yeaTs, arriving at the quantity used in this way in exactly the same way as we arrived at the quantity of imported sugar used ' in previous years. We sold to these people at a lower rate than was charged to the Australian public generally. It was a much lower rate, and although I cannot recall the exact amount I believe it was about £8 per ton. It was in excess of the actual amount of duty, which was £6 per ton; but that was during the war. We then reached a period when the world's parity for sugar was infinitely higher than the Australian price, but we did not turn round and charge the jam manufacturers and fruit preservers the world's parity for the sugar used in tha manufacture of jams for export as we might have done. We gave them the sugar at the Australian price, because we considered it desirable to give every possible encouragement to the jam manufacturers to pay the fruit-growers a reasonable price and thus assist in building up the export trade to the utmost of our ability. We have now reached a time when that does not apply, as the world's parity for sugar is below the Australian price. We are making arrangements, which I trust will be completed without delay, under which it will be possible to give assistance in some way. I am not binding myself in any sense, because negotiations are in progress, but we are conferring with the jam manufacturers and ' the fruit preservers concerning the price of the sugar used in manufactures for export purposes, the intention being to allow the manufacturers of jams and canned fruits for export to obtain sugar at as cheap a rate as they could purchase it anywhere in the world.
- That is during the period of control.

- Yes, and that will last another two seasons, under the agreement . already entered into. The latest reports from Queensland concerning the sugar crop indicate that, notwithstanding the magnificent promises in the early part of the season, we shall this year have to import considerable quantities of sugar. It. is, however, a fact, and one which I very much regret. We hope to be able to make such arrangements as to enable them to secure sugar used in the manufacture of exports only at as low a price as they could purchase it anywhere in the world. I was asked by an honorable member as to whether any manufacturers were getting that concession now, and I can assure him that they are not.

speech.para: Item agreed to.
Item 29 (Invert sugar,&c).

talk.start.para: .- Will the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Greene) explain what invert sugar and invert syrup means ?
- I might just as well be perfectly frank and say that I do not know, but I suppose that invert sugar is a sugar produced by some special means of manufacture.
- It consists of larger crystals.
- The duty is exactly the same, and I presume it is sugar used in some special process of manufacture.

. - It is desirable that we should have some information on this item, and as I believe that the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. ' Corser) is the only authority in the Chamber on this subject, perhaps he will explain the difference between ordinary sugar and invert sugar.
- I have already said that it consists of larger crystals.

speech.para: Item agreed to.
Item 30 (Sugar, n.e.i.), item 31 (Golden Syrup,&c.), and item 32 (Molasses) agreed to. divisioniv.- agricultural products and groceries.
Item 33 (Animal foods, n.e.i.) agreed to.
Item34(Animalfoods,n.e.i.)agreed to.

talk.start.para: .- Will the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Greene) explain the reason for imposing a tax on imported animals. The amount of duty is likely to be so small as to make the item appear almost ridiculous. I am sure it will not have the effect of preventing animals coming into the Commonwealth.
. - The honorable member for ' Robertson (Mr. Fleming) is doubtless referring to stud animals which are exempt under this item.
- But what of common stock ?

- I do not attach much importance to the item, but a similar line has been in the Tariff for years. There are some islands adjacent to the mainland - I forget the names - suitable for pastoral purposes, and there is a possibility of stock coming from these sources or from Java or Noumea. With the honorable member I admit that there is not much in the item, but I did not feel disposed to have it removed.
.- Possibly the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Greene) has not received any revenue from this source, and doubtless it is like the duty imposed on wheat, which,

speech.para: Tariff. [13May,1921.] Tariff. 8477 at the only time it was likely to be of any use, was removed. I think it is unnecessary to cumber the Tariff schedule with an item of this character which we can well do without. I shall move that it be struck out.

talk.start.para: .- The honorable member for Swan (Mr. Prowse) will secure the object he has in view by simply voting against the item. Although the duty is not large, a fairly considerable number of animals are brought into the Commonwealth. For instance, well over 800 horses were brought in last year.
- Out of how many millions.
- At all events, we get a little revenue from this source when these animals are brought in.
- Brought in for stud purposes?
- No; all stud animals are free. I think that since we get a little revenue from the item we might as well retain it.

. -I still think that the item should be struck out. The Minister admits that it is practically of no value, and he has given no reason for its retention. The revenue derived from it must be so small that it is not worth taking into account, and since it is undoubtedly another of those little annoyances to which the primary producer is subjected, I think we ought to omit it.

speech.para: Item agreed to.
Item 35 (Annatto) ; item 36 (Arrowroot) ; item 37 (Bacon and hams); and item 38 (Biscuits) agreed to.
Item 39 (Blue laundry).

talk.start.para: . - I desire to ask whether we make laundry blue in Australia, and if we can produce sufficient to meet the local demand. Laundry blue is an article of universal use, and we should make it as cheap as possible.
- We are making vast quantities of laundry blue in Australia, and can provide for all our requirements in respect of it.

speech.para: Item agreed to.
Item -40 (Broom corn millet and rice straw).

talk.start.para: .- I want to bring under the notice of the Minister for Trade and Customs (Mr. Greene) the position of farmers who are growing millet. Quite a number of men on the land in New South Wales and Queensland are growing millet, But they find it difficult to carry ou because of the competition of the inferior Italian production.' Millet is grown on the Lower Hunter, the Manning, and Richmond Rivers, as well as at Yanco and Tamworth. A good deal is grown in my own electorate.
- And also in Queensland.

-Yes. The duty is only 4s. per cental. That protection is insufficient, and growers have written to me stating that with such a duty it is impossible to profitably carry on. The Japanese are sending in, for broom making purposes, an inferior millet which is being largely used. I have two letters, which I shall read to the Committee, in order to show that our farmers arc dissatisfied with the present duty. Here is one written by Mr. Cunningham on behalf of the farmers of Nelson Plains, shortly after the Tariff schedule was laid on the table -

quote.para: Dear Mr. Charlton, - I am directed by the Nelson Plains Progress Association to ask you to urge upon the Minister for Customs the necessity of raising the Tariff on imported broom millet in order to save an Australian industry from absolute extinction. We understand that the Tariff will be dealt with immediately Parliament reassembles, and would respectfully urge that you use your best endeavours to have the Tariff raised at least fourfold. As you are not, perhaps, familiar with the subject, I will try briefly to make the matter plain to you. The areas in which broom millet is grown in New South Wales are the Lower Hunter, and Manning and Richmond Bivers on the coast, and smaller quantities inland at Yanco and Tamworth districts. The amount grown in these districts is quite sufficent to supply Australia and New Zealand in any season, and consequently there is no need to import any from outside. At the present time millet is quoted at £50 per ton of 2,000 lbs. in Sydney, but very little is being sold for that, the average price being from £30 to £40, which is altogether too low a price to pay farmers at the present high cost of living. This low range of prices has been brought about by the action of the manufacturers and speculators forming a ring and importing, to date. 120 tons from Italy, although there axe ample stocks of Australian millet awaiting sale in all the millet-growing districts. Last year they succeeded in inducing the Federal Government to place an embargo on the exportation of millet to Kew Zealand, although then, as now, there were ample stocks to supply both countries, and this action was taken without consulting the growers, who were certainly entitled to have a say in the matter. To show you how the manufacturers score at the expense of the growers - The price of millet is no better, or hardly as good, as before the war, when you could buy a broom - retail - in any shop in the State for ls. 6d., whereas at the present time brooms range from 3s. Od. to 4s., and the cost of production to the grower has gone up 200. per cent. Trusting you will do your best in this matter,
Yours respectfully,

item.label: M.
item.para: Cunningham.

quote.para: P.S. - If you require any further facts or figures in this matter I shall be happy to furnish them. - M.C.

speech.para: Most honorable members are familiar with this district, where a great deal of millet is grown. I have also a letter from a resident of Miller's Forest, where probably more millet is grown than in any other part of New South Wales -

quote.para: Dear Mr. Charlton, - On behalf of the farmers of the Hunter Valley I wish to draw your attention with a view of having it placed before the Federal authorities of the treatment meted out to the millet-growers of this locality, as to importations of millet from other countries. Owing to the cost of labour, the price paid for the cultivation, raising, and cutting of this crop was nearly 100 per cent. more this season than in past years, and when the first millet was harvested, as early as December last, the price offered for this millet was £80 per ton at the shed. This is just a payable price, and nothing more. A few weeks later what do we find ? The " profiteers " have got their heads together, and to-day we are very lucky if we can get £40 per ton for it at the shed. Do you not consider this an injustice, and on top of this the Federal Government is allowing foreign countries to simply flood the country with so-called Italian millet. Is this a fair go? The past seasons may have been good to some farmers, but others have simply to depend upon this crop to meet their rents, &c, and what is to become of the poor struggling farmer when, on the 1st of July this year, he has to sacrifice his crop for the paltry sum of £40 per ton when it costs him nearly £30 per ton to raise same f We consider it a grave injustice, and I think you would earn the esteem and appreciation of all the millet-growers in New South Wales if you would ventilate this matter on the floor of the House. What we want is to get the Tariff increased, and an inquiry made into this matter. Hoping to hear from you in the course of a few weeks,

item.label: A.
item.para: J. O'Brien. Secretary.

speech.para: I ask the Minister to increase the duty on this item. It is far too small at present.

talk.start.para: - What do you suggest should be the amount?

- It should be sufficient to prevent effective competition by the inferior stuff from overseas, which threatens to kill the millet-growing industry in Australia. Manufacturers get hold of it, use it for the trade, and then they charge the very highest prices for the product as if it were Australian millet.
- The Japanese product is killing the local industry.

- The honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. West) has just told me that the manufacturers mix this inferior stuff at the factories, but the fact remains that our farmers are growing enough millet for the whole of the Australian and New Zealand requirements.

. - I have much pleasure in supporting the remarks made by the honorable member for Hunter (Mr. Charlton). I have rather intimate knowledge of the conditions under which millet is grown in the northeastern districts of Victoria, and recently I introduced a deputation to the Minister for Customs asking for a higher duty in this schedule. The gentlemen who comprised the deputation furnished me with a number of facts which I should like to place before the Committee. They are to the point, and tell us just what the growers want. The growers say -

quote.para: Broom millet is grown in Victoria principally in the valleys of the King and Ovens Rivers in the north-eastern part of the State, and in New South Wales in the Hunter River district and similar country. The output annually averages 250 tons in Victoria, and 550 tons in New South Wales, of fibre. The land most suitable for its cultivation ' is a rich alluvial loam. The cultivation method usually adopted is to plough the ground as soon as conditions permit after winter, harrow twice, then subsequently either plough a second time or utilize a cultivator, and again harrow to produce a fine tilth before seeding. Seed is sown by drilling as soon as warm weather sets in, say, from the middle of October to the middle of December, in rows 30 inches apart. It is usual to fertilize with superphosphate during growth of crop, and cultivation between the rows is carried on in order to retain moisture and capillarity, and develop root growth.

The harvesting of fibre commences when seed heads begin to ripen, and is done by manual labour. The plants are bent down, and the man cutting, using a sharp knife, cuts through the stalk about 4 inches down from the fibre, the object of retaining the short length of stalk being for convenience sake in subsequent handling. The fibre is laid down on the prostrated plants to dry until carted in, in small sheaves, to the drying sheds, where it is spread out until completely cured. It is then ready to be threshed. Threshing is accomplished by a crew of seven or eight men. It consists of holding the fibre in handfuls on a spiked roller which is revolved at high speed, and tears off all seeds from fibre. The roller machine is generally worked by means of an internal combustion engine of from 4 to 5 B.H.P. When threshing is completed the fibre is compressed into kales, wired round, and is then ready to despatch to factory, where it is made up into the finished broom.

speech.para: The cost of production is estimated as follows: - Assuming it to be a good crop of broom, and basing its yield at 1 ton of threshed fibre to 3 acres, which is above the average on Government Statistician's figures, the production costs on lowest possible estimate are : -

added to which are railage, commission, storage, and handling charges, and cost of production to growers will amount to £25 or £26. This is the estimate of a good crop; but on reviewing figures supplied by Statists of Victoria and New South Wales, it was found that over the triennial period of 1917-1919, the yield was 5 cwt., 5 cwt., and 2½ cwt. respectively, and with prices fluctuating from £28 to £71 per ton, and averaging throughout £49 per ton, the gross return to the grower amounted to £9 8s. Id. per acre per annum, which, on estimate of cost, left little margin over expenses involved.

The work of growing and harvesting broom is mostly done by settlers on small holdings, assisted by their families or hired labour. Of the total cost of production, i.e., £25 per ton, rather more than four-fifths is paid out for labour alone, and estimating the yield of the fibre' in the King Valley this season to be 200 tons, it means that £4,000 is spent during the season amongst the workers engaged, which sum is of considerable importance to them in making up a living wage. The work is of an exacting nature, and fills all hours of daylight.

It has been found that fibre has been imported from overseas, principally Italy and Japan at as low a cost as £11 per ton landed, and this season at about £32. The existing Tariff is £4 per ton, but the producers are strongly of opinion that to afford some measure of protection and security a duty of not less than £14 per ton should be imposed. It is recognised that a price lower than £40 per ton is hardly remunerative to the grower.

It is pointed out in this connexion that when instituting inquiries into the manufacturing processes and costs, it was confidentially stated by a manufacturer that factory costs when the price of fibre was £70 per ton were about 2s. per broom, made up as: - Cost of fibre, at £70 per ton,1s. 2d.; cost of handles, wire, varnish, and making broom, 6d. ; overhead factory charges, 4d.; total, 2s. These figures were given when cost of material was at high war-time level, and, pursuing the inquiries further, it was found the retail price to the consumer averaged 5s. per broom, so that cost of distribution amounted to more than primary and manufacturing costs combined.

It will be seen that for every £10 per ton paid to growers for fibre, the cost of fibre in each broom would be 2d., in other words, at £40 per ton fibre, per broom 8d.; at £50, 10d.; at £60,1s., and so on, which is proportionally low to cost of broom . to ultimate consumer. Should the growers be denied this necessary protection, it will mean the practical extermination of an industry of value to the country.. All the fibre consumed can readily be grown within Australia without recourse to imported cheap labour stuff. It is an industry' essentially adapted to small settlers, or settlers' sons, to give continuity of employment throughout the year.

During a recent tour of the King Valley, it was found that several repatriated soldiers had grown fibre either on shares or on their holdings. The crops generally were good, but settlers were dispirited as to prices likely to be obtainable, and felt themselves to be unfairly at the mercy of the Associated Manufacturers, who depress the market at will, assisted to that end mainly by the low Tariff on importations. That is the statement of men who grow this product, and have gone into the facts and figures of the case very carefully. If is an industry which I consider should have some protection. Up to the present I have taken no part in the discussion of the Tariff, but I submit that if Protection is to be the settled policy of the country our primary producers must have their reasonable share.

Mr.CORSER (Wide Bay) [4.0].- This millet and rice straw industry was started in Queensland years ago, and was successful until dumping took place, and numbers of growers found that they could not get anything like a payable price. Queensland has ample room for this industry, and is as suitable for it as any part of the world, but there must be protection against dumping especially from Japan. Paddy or bill rice straw has been grown, to my knowledge, very successfully in Queensland. I imported, years ago, a quantity of rice seed for testing purposes, and the results were splendid. I am sure that with proper protection a flourishing industry could be built up in many parts of Australia in growing millet and rice straw, affording ample employment for our returned soldiers and the immigrants whom we hope will come to Australia.

talk.start.para: .- When the Tariff was framed, and broom, corn, millet, and rice straw were left at 4s. per cental, broom was then bringing the high price of something like £80 per ton, and I did not feel justified in suggesting an increase of duty. Circumstances, however, have materially altered,, and we now find ourselves in a different position. Importations are coming in at comparatively low prices, and in all probability it will be necessary to make some adjustment. £ had not expected to reach this item before next Wednesday, and I have to thank honorable members for the progress that has been made.

speech.para: Progress reported.

debate.para: Bill returned from the Senate without amendment.

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - In the Argus this morning there is a report ef a speech by the honorable member for Cowper and the Leader of the Country party (Dr. Earle Page) delivered at a meeting of country press delegates in this city. The report contains the following : -

quote.para: Dr. Earle Page said that during the last three years £60,000,000 had been practically squandered in repatriation. In several years he did not suppose there would be more than £3.000,000 or £4,000,000 worth of tangible assets.

speech.para: At the present time we hear a great deal about economy; but I think that honorable members who have knowledge of the facts connected with the various repatriation schemes of the Government ought to make their meaning quite clear when they speak of the. squandering of £60,000,000.

I am not prepared to admit for one moment that this money has been squandered. Of course, in connexion with repatriation, as in other matters, errors of judgment may have been made. lt is not to be expected that we can place 300,000 men in the industries of the country without errors, or a certain amount of overlapping between Commonwealth and State. But to say that the whole of the money to be expended has been squandered is to use language not justified by the actual facts. I should like to ask the Leader of the Country party whether he is correctly reported, because I do not wish to belabour him unnecessarily or unduly.

talk.start.para: - He has been reported to the same effect on another occasion.

- Without desiring to initiate a debate on the- whole administration of the Repatriation Department, I think that the honorable member should say exactly what he meant when he referred in this sweeping way to the squandering of public money.
- The honorable member has made the same statement in the House.
- The Leader of the Country party is further reported -

quote.para: In several years he did not suppose there would be ' more than £3,000,000 or £4,000,000 worth of tangible assets.

talk.start.para: - I am of that opinion.
- The honorable member is entitled to his opinion, just as I claim to be entitled to mine.
- Is the honorable member for Cowper (Dr. Earle Page) not entitled to his opinion?
- Of course, but honorable members here have serious responsibilities, and should bc able to give facts when they make such statements as are attributed to the honorable member.
- Do you think we shall get all that money owing for the War Service Homes ?
- Up to date the percentage of men who have failed is remarkably small -I doubt if it is 1 percent.
- That is all right, but we have a long way to go yet.
- The transfer of War Service Homes is confined entirely to returned soldiers, and I am not prepared to allow them to be maligned in this way.
- They cannot pay the money.

speech.para: Mr.BURCHELL.- I must say that the honorable member for Maranoa (Mr. James Page) has always been sympathetic towards the returned men.

talk.start.para: - Quite so, but I know that it is impossible for them to repay this money.

speech.para: Mr.BURCHELL. - I disagree with the honorable member; and again there is a conflict of opinion. However, I wish to know whether the honorable member for Cowper is correctly reported in the Argus, and, further, I would like the Assistant Minister for Repatriation (Mr. Rodgers) to give the facts, so that they may be placed on record in juxtaposition to the statements of the honorable member.

talk.start.para: . - I am not surprised, in the case of a statement of this character made by a leader of a party in the House, that the first opportunity should be seized by the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Burchell), himself a returned soldier, to bring it under the notice of the House and of the country. It is to me a most astounding statement, and I had expected a flat denial from the honorable member for Cowper (Dr. Earle Page), not so much of the general sweeping statements, but of the figures attributed to him. . The matter was to-day brought under my notice by the honorable member for Fremantle, and I shall read the statement attributed to the honorable member for Cowper -

quote.para: Dr. Earle Page said that during the last three years £60,000,000 had been practically squandered in repatriation. In several years he did not suppose there would be more than £3,000,000 or £4,000,000 worth of tangible assets. The reason was that we had not had » post-war programme ready, simply because the city press was predominant over the country press.

speech.para: I am not concerned about the latter reason, but I am concerned as to the effect such a statement will have on those who do not possess a personal or close knowledge of the facts.. I speak of those outside of Australia, as well as those who have great financial responsibilities in this country. For the information of the honorable member for Cowper, I wish to say that the expenditure up to date amounts to £79,790,701. The following table shows the details: -

quote.para: Repatriation Benefits to ex-Australian Imperialforce Men.
Expenditure by the Commonwealth Government in connexion with repatriation up to 31st March, 1920, is as follows: -

speech.para: The statement of the honorable member for Cowper pre-supposes that the purchase of land and the erection of War Service Homes have been carried put and administered by six incompetent States, and that the land and houses are in the hands of incompetent soldiers, who are unable to carry the proposition through, or must be regarded as men who cannot be trusted to discharge their financial obligations. Some 16,000 houses have been built or are in course of construction, and of the £10,970,903 expended I am pleased to say that up to date over £800,000 has been repaid by. the soldiers, evidencing the appreciation with which they regard the acquisition of their homes. I invite honorable members, notwithstanding press and public criticism outside, to make an inspection of these soldiers' homes, which, I am sure, they will find are not deserving of the adverse criticism that is heard of them to-day. I do not seek at at this stage to justify the whole administration in connexion with War Service Homes, nor do I think the Minister himself would desire to do so. There have been shortcomings; but it must be said, in justice, that the Commissioner fell on bad times. He, just as did private builders who undertook extensive operations, found himself up against short markets and harassing industrial conditions, and, generally, the most difficult period of building activity Australia has ever known. Yet there are men going round this country to-day who are more concerned in securing publicity for themselves than in taking any true interest in the soldiers or the welfare of their country. Instead of endeavouring to be of assistance and encouragement, they are denouncing every action of the Government in their endeavour to disparage our efforts to fulfil the nation's obligation' to returned soldiers. It would be far more fitting if these persons were to offer commonsense advice rather than mischievous and self-aggrandizing criticism. For a responsible member of this House, and he the Leader of a party, to say that an expenditure of some £60,000,000 will be reduced to an abiding asset of only about £3,000,000 or £4,000,000 is a statement which no child would take notice of. Such a remark brings more denunciation upon its maker than upon those at whom his reckless and ill-considered accusations are aimed. Frankly, I do not understand the purpose of the honorable member. I am prepared to listen to and, if necessary, to combat any criticism of an honest and well-intended nature concerning any branch of administration with which I have had to do. And I am certain that the Minister for Repatriation would be readily prepared to say the same for himself. I invite the honorable member to investigate the plight in which men with life-long experience in the building trade have been finding themselves. They have been metaphorically choked with dear material, and have been unable to sell it, or in any way, in fact, to get it out. The Commonwealth has certain stock in hand which has cost much money; but there is no trader of any magnitude in Australia who is not in a similar position.

With respect to land settlement, I have painted out that a sum of £25,000.000 has been spent in the acquisition of land. In that regard, the Commonwealth Government cannot accept the entire responsibility.

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer himself said the other day that there should have been some Commonwealth control.

- Perhaps that is so. But a huge co-partnership was entered into between Commonwealth and States, in which the former undertook to find the money on loan, and the latter to find the land and generally administer and organize its settlement. Is the Commonwealth Government to be held entirely responsible for every purchase made by each State, and for every phase of activity in each State?
- Seeing that the Commonwealth Government found the money, they surely should have secured some control.

- Perhaps the Government should have exercised some closer form of supervision; but it would have; been impossible to have overlapping control and clashing authority. I ask the honorable member not to be specially concerned with what is, after all, a passing phase of Australia's difficulties. I am one of those who believe that the bottom has not dropped out of the situation. I think I can see the elements of a great post-war revival throughout the world. The settlement of the reparations question with Germany may mean the inauguration of a great trade revival which will astonish the world. Our present troubles are an inevitable phase of the world's post-war crises. I repeat that the remarks of the honorable member for Cowper were not worthy of him and of his position.

The procedure adopted in connexion with this matter was grossly unfair to myself, to my colleagues of the Country party, and to the House generally. It was not proper for a Government Whip, practically without notice and in the last hour of the week's proceedings, to bring forward a matter of this nature, or for the Minister to make a reply such as he has done. To begin with, I repudiate the Minister's assertion that my statements have been made with any desire to secure personal notoriety. As for that matter, I invite the House and the public to judge between the Minister and myself concerning our respective war-time activities, and in the matter of our repatriation activities since the war. I also repudiate his statement that my utterances were either incorrect or ridiculous. I was substantially right when I remarked that, approximately, £60,000,000 had been spent upon repatriation generally, apart from pensions, and that within a few years there were likely to be only a few million pounds' worth of tangible assets left. In passing, I desire to mention that the newspaper reports of my remarks to the country press were condensed. I stated that the city press had always created public opinion in Australia, and that, by reason of that fact, matters had been permitted to go on to a degree which would never have been allowed had there been a provincial press strong enough to forma body of country opinion which could be reckoned with, and would expose some of the failures under its own notice.

speech.para: Regarding the statement that the Commonwealth Government are responsible for the position which exists to-day, I emphasize that they are responsible for the fact that, after having spent £79,000,000 upon our returned soldiers they will be very considerably short of that total sum - even if the best should happen - when the day of settlement arrives. At no time in the history of Australia could so huge an amount as £79,000,000 have been spent upon public developmental work with so little to show for it.

talk.start.para: - What rot that is. Are war pensions and war gratuities to be regarded as reproductive works?

- Knowing that my time is limited, the honorable member is endeavouring to curtail it by running interjections. In my opinion, this Government and Parliament stand condemned for the inadequacy of the provision which was made during the war period for post-war reconstruction. The Government had a wonderful chance. But what happened ? The men who went overseas to fight for this country returned full of spirit and anxious to settle down to civil avocations straight away. But, instead of being able to do so, some of them have been waiting more than eighteen months to get upon the land. Their hearts have been broken, their hopes have been dashed, and to-day scores of soldiers who, only a few years ago were eager to fight for us, labour under a. definite sense of grievance against the Government' of their own country.
- Are we responsible for delays in land settlement?

- Yes; finding the money ought to give some control. Immediately after Senator E. D. Millen became Minister for Repatriation, he admitted that the plan for repatriating our soldiers would have to shape itself. It has done so. It has meandered all over the map, without taking any particular shape. It has resembled the world before the Creation, in that it has been "without form and void."
- The Creation turned out a pretty good job anyhow.

- Whilst we were doing nothing, every other country was attempting to do something in regard to post-war reconstruction. In England, during 1916, a Minister for Reconstruction was appointed. The authorities there endeavoured to arrange that as soon as the war was over, the machinery which had been brought into being for purposes of destruction should be used for purposes of reconstruction. I know that it is nob a proper thing to depreciate one's own country, and I do not indulge in those tactics. There is still plenty of opportunity to redeem the past, and to achieve something worth while. I have no desire to blacken the record of the Government. But I do say that the soldier is not getting a fair deal. Whether that statement upsets the Government or not, is a matter of indifference to me. But the men who fought for us a year or two ago, to-day have a definite grievance against us. In Canada the authorities were making plans for repatriating the soldiers of that Dominion in the middle of 1917.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Sir JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - The Canadian authorities have not done half as much in that direction as we have done.

- At any rate, Colonel Dodge, who passed through Grafton some eighteen months ago, and who had travelled through every British Dominion investigating what had been done in regard to soldier repatriation, informed me that when he was there shortly before, that control was so decentralized that a soldier in Canada would be able to go along to the local Repatriation Committee upon one day, select his block, and draw his allowance of £625 for plant upon the following day. But here delays have continually occurred. The Assistant Minister for Repatriation (Mr. Rodgers) has said that we are not responsible for land settlement.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Sir JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Who told the honorable member all this?
- Colonel Dodge.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Sir JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Then why in the name of mischief has he not done it?

- He was desirous of settling the whole of his battalion in one area. After travelling through all the Dominions he did not choose Australia as the country in which to make that settlement, notwithstanding that he would have preferred to settle his men in this country because of its climate, if the thing could have been managed at all.
- He may live to be sorry for his action.
- He may. If we had a decent and comprehensive system of repatriation or immigration he would be sorry.
- We have already settled hundreds of ex-Imperial soldiers in Australia.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Sir JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Is not the financial trouble at the bottom of all this? We have an obligation of £70,000,000 or £80,000,000 to meet in one or two years.

- In New South Wales, Mr. Ashford, Minister for Lands, has admitted that though he has resumed land at £10 and £11 per acre, he was willing to sell it to the soldiers for £6 or £7 per acre because it is not worth more.
- That is a condemnation of his own Government, but not of this Government.

- Thus, in some cases, up to 50 per cent. of the value of the resumed lands has departed. A good deal has been said in regard to the payments for War Service Homes. But the Commonwealth Surveyor-General admitted the other day, in evidence, that too much land had been bought at boom prices, and one particular block was mentioned, which had been purchased in Newcastle, which was frequently 9 inches under water during a good portion of the year.
- That land was bought upon his recommendation.

- I have seen house after house built and bought which are already showing signs of disintegration and decay. To say that these houses will be worth even half of their present value twenty years hence is ridiculous.
- The honorable member has not had much experience of real estate.

- That may be thb honorable member's opinion, but it is certainly not the opinion of those who know me intimately. Only last year the War Service Homes Commissioner purchased a saw-mill property in Queensland for £500,000. The statement has been made that if the mill is kept working for ten years, and if timber maintains its then price, the Department will make a considerable profit out of the transaction. But if that mill be worked at the present time, the Commonwealth will unquestionably sustain a loss upon it of many hundreds of thousands of pounds, in addition to the £500,000 which it cost. I make that statement deliberately, and I claim to know something about saw-mills.
- The answer to that statement is that the Commission which inquired into the matter held that the purchase was justified under the circumstances.
- Much of the money spent by the Repatriation Department has gone in the way of sustenance allowance simply because we had no comprehensive scheme of repatriation.
- The Department tried to make the men cadgers.

- Many members of the local Repatriation Committees have had to pay money to our returned soldiers out of their own pockets merely because the methods adopted by the Department were so slow. Yet the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) and myself have outlined comprehensive schemes of soldier settlement which would have permitted the utilization of large areas of Crown lands. In my own district, for an expenditure of £7,000,000 or £8,000,000 in railway construction and a hydroelectric scheme, with an additional £5,000,000 for resumption purposes, the Government could have immediately added to 6,000,000 acres of land a capital value of at least £130,000,000, and this would have been a continually growing asset. Of this area 70 per cent. would have been Crown land unavailable for settlement by reason of inaccessibility under present conditions. When one recollects these facts he is led to wonder why our entire scheme of repatriation has resolved itself into the building of a few houses around the capitals of the States and in other places where their value is ultimately bound to depreciate.
- Before whom did the honorable member put his proposals ?

- They were put before Mr. Holman, the then Premier of New South Wales. They were brought before the Commonwealth Government in 1918, and again before the Repatriation Conference of Federal and State Governments in 1919, by Mr. Ball, the late Minister for Railways in New South Wales, and Mr. Holman, the then Premier.

- The arrangements made between the Commonwealth and the States at the various conferences do not prevent the States from carrying out the honorable member's scheme ox any other that may appeal to them.

- I have made no charge against this Government; but I say that on the whole this money has been so spent that after a few years the asset that will be created will be comparatively small and diminishing, while it could have been spent in a way which would have created an enormously valuable asset, and an increasing asset. There were possibilities in the scheme suggested by the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser) and myself. Not simply would it have resulted in an increase in the value of the land taken up, but it would also have utilized soldiers and officers who had been properly trained abroad. Of the men coming back, 60 per cent had no jobs. Among them were many officers who had risen from the ranks, who during four or five years of war service, had learned to manage commissariats and to control bodies of men, and might thus have made ideal captains of industry. Had returned soldiers been put on to improve land, and to build subsidiary transport and power, they would have been usefully employed from the start, and practically the whole of the Australian Imperial Force could have been absorbed in two or three schemes, which would have created an asset worth £200,000,000.
- A large area of Crown land has been settled by soldiers in Victoria and the other States.

- How much has been so settled in Kew South Wales 1 We know what has occurred in connexion with projects built in New South Wales with repatriation money, and the result of similar expenditure in Queensland. If a co-operative scheme like that of the honorable member for Swan (Mr. Prowse) had been put before the soldiers before the war gratuity proposal was dealt with, a great deal of the money that has gone in payment of this gratuity could have been devoted to co-operative effort instead of being spent aimlessly by reason of want of immediate employment. However, there are still large sums to be spent, and although much evil has been done in the past, there is no reason why we should throw away millions more. Expenditure should be directed towards practical objects, in the manner I have suggested.
- I agree with that, and a Committee is at work.

.- I take it that the honorable member for Cowper (Dr. Earle Page) desires to assist the Government by the suggestions that he has made, and I have the same object in view. I would like Ministers to bear it in mind that every man who went to the Front was the soldier, not of a State, but of Australia, and the obligation towards the returned men is primarily that of the Commonwealth, and not of the States ; though if the States will assist us well and good.

speech.para: Another matter to which I wish to direct attention is the stoppage of pensions. Men -and women complain to me that their pensions have been stopped, and they do not know why. I should like the Minister to issue the instruction that when an allowance or pension is stopped, notification shall be sent to the person concerned, together with a statement of the reasons for the action taken. That would prevent a lot of trouble.

Every soldier who went to the war from the United States of America could insure his life up to £2,000 at a minimum of cost, but in Australia he would have had to pay a premium of £200 for that insurance. If a man did not apply personally to be insured, he was insured automatically. I should like the Minister to address a letter to the authorities of Canada, South Africa, and the United States, the three countries in which conditions are most like our own, asking what is being done there for returned soldiers. When the information has been obtained, I should like a table to be prepared setting forth that Australia has done such-and-such things,' and Canada, South Africa, and the United States of America such other things. If we have done better than any other country in helping our returned men, the more honour to us, and, if not, the knowledge of what they are doing may stimulate us to greater efforts.

talk.start.para: - I shall shortly give the House a comparative statement about pensions.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
